verses.roman:
buddhye rame ātmārāma--dui ta' prakāra
'paṇḍita' muni-gaṇa, nirgrantha 'mūrkha' āra

synonyms: buddhye—in intelligence; rame—who enjoys; ātmārāma—is ātmārāma; dui ta ' prakāra—two varieties; paṇḍita—learned; muni-gaṇa—philosophers; nirgrantha—without education; mūrkha—foolish; āra—also.
translation: "Everyone has some kind of intelligence, and one who utilizes his intelligence is called ātmārāma. There are two types of ātmārāma. One is a learned scholar and a philosopher, and the other is an uneducated, illiterate and foolish person.
